node.title: San Francisco Restaurant Apologizes for Asking 3 Police Officers to Leave
node.alt: Yelp reviewers left hundreds of one-star reviews for the San Francisco restaurant Hilda and Jesse after its staff members asked three police officers to leave on Friday.
node.description: The uniformed officers had just sat down when staff members asked them to leave because the workers felt uncomfortable about the officersâ€™ weapons, the restaurant said.
node.content: ["Three uniformed San Francisco police officers sat down for a meal on Friday at an all-day breakfast restaurant.", "But it was not long before staff members of the restaurant, Hilda and Jesse, \u201cfelt uncomfortable with the presence of their multiple weapons\u201d and \u201cpolitely asked\u201d the officers to leave, the restaurant said on Instagram on Saturday.", "That request drew widespread attention, with the San Francisco police chief criticizing the move and hundreds of people leaving negative ratings on the restaurant\u2019s Yelp page.", "The police chief, William Scott, said in a statement on Twitter: \u201cThe San Francisco Police Department stands for safety with respect, even when it means respecting wishes that our officers and I find discouraging and personally disappointing.", "\u201cI believe the vast majority of San Franciscans welcome their police officers, who deserve to know that they are appreciated for the difficult job we ask them to do \u2014 in their uniforms \u2014 to keep our neighborhoods and businesses safe.\u201d", "In its statement on Saturday, the restaurant doubled down, saying that it would welcome members of the Police Department \u201cwhen they are off duty, out of uniform, and without their weapons.\u201d", "\u201cThis is not a political statement, we did what we thought was best for our staff,\u201d the restaurant added.", "In a separate statement, Rachel Sillcocks, one of the owners of Hilda and Jesse, said: \u201cOur restaurant is a safe space \u2014 particularly for queer and bipoc individuals. Furthermore, the fact that they were in uniform with multiple weapons on them made our staff uncomfortable, and potentially other guests.", "\u201cWe\u2019re sorry that the decision upset you,\u201d she continued. \u201cWe understand your perspective and we hope you\u2019ll consider ours.\u201d", "On Sunday, the owners of the restaurant, Kristina Liedags Compton and Ms. Sillcocks, apologized on Instagram.", "\u201cWe hope this will be a teachable moment for us as we repair and continue to build bridges with the SFPD,\u201d the statement said, adding that \u201cwe handled this badly.\u201d", "The restaurant and the Police Department did not respond to emails and phone calls on Sunday night.", "However, Ms. Sillcocks told KGO-TV on Sunday that the restaurant\u2019s response had \u201cnothing to do with the fact that they were officers.\u201d", "\u201cIt is about the fact that we do not allow weapons in our restaurant,\u201d she said.", "Dean Preston, a member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, said on Twitter on Sunday that \u201carmed police make some folks feel safer and others feel less safe.\u201d", "\u201cThat\u2019s just a fact,\u201d he said.", "The owners\u2019 apology came too late to stop a torrent of angry Yelp reviewers, who left hundreds of one-star reviews on the restaurant\u2019s page. Many of the reviewers were not based in San Francisco and had nothing to say about the restaurant\u2019s selection of breakfast foods, including pancakes and avocado on sweet potato.", "Instead, some of the reviewers criticized the restaurant\u2019s decision to ask the officers to leave and called for a boycott, while others supported the request.", "\u201cI refuse to eat here again because you refused to serve on-duty police officers,\u201d one reviewer wrote in a one-star review.", "Another reviewer from San Francisco left a five-star review, writing, \u201cThanks but I don\u2019t want a gun with my waffles,\u201d and adding that \u201cSan Francisco is San Francisco for a reason!\u201d", "The restaurant on Sunday averaged a one-star rating, although Yelp \u201ctemporarily disabled\u201d new reviews on the page.", "What happened at Hilda and Jesse is not the first time restaurants have drawn attention for asking officers to leave or refusing them service.", "In 2019, six police officers said they were asked to leave a Starbucks in Tempe, Ariz., after an \u201canxious, nervous or uncomfortable\u201d customer asked a barista why the officers were there. The coffee company apologized on Twitter and in full-page newspaper ads, and the hashtag #BoycottStarbucks picked up steam on social media.", "In 2015, within weeks of each other, two employees refused service to police officers at popular chains in two different states, but then said they were joking.", "One was an employee at Dunkin\u2019 Donuts, now known as Dunkin\u2019, who spotted a police officer in the back of the line in West Hartford, Conn., and then announced, \u201cHe didn\u2019t get the message; we don\u2019t serve cops here.\u201d The other was an employee of an Arby\u2019s in Pembroke Pines, Fla., who refused to serve a uniformed police officer at a drive-through window."]
